section.title: Overview
section.p: All the words are analysed with dictionary form + grammatical tags. Each tag is introduced with a "+" sign. We thus have

biila+N+Sg+Acc
boahtit+V+Ind+Prs+Sg1
The following tags are defined in the lexicon file (in the beginning of the sme-lex.txt file, and correspondingly, with other tags, for the other languages):
section.source:
! Tags for POS +N +A +Adv +V +Pron +CS +CC +Adp +Po +Pr +Interj +Pcle +Num +Prop
! Tags for Inflection +Pers +Dem +Interr +Refl +Recipr +Rel +Indef +Ess +Sg +Du +Pl +Nom +Gen +Acc +Ill +Loc +Com +isuf +asuf +Cmpnd +Cmpnd+ +Guess +PxSg1 +PxSg2 +PxSg3 +PxDu1 +PxDu2 +PxDu3 +PxPl1 +PxPl2 +PxPl3 +Comp +Superl +Qst +Foc +Attr +Card +Ord !+Clt (removed bec. of clarity) +Pass +Ind +Prs +Prt +Pot +Cond +Imprt +Sg1 +Sg2 +Sg3 +Du1 +Du2 +Du3 +Pl1 +Pl2 +Pl3 +Inf +Ger +ConNeg +Neg +ImprtII +PrsPrc +PrfPrc +Sup +VGen +VAbess +Actio +Actor +ABBR +ACR +CLB +PUNCT +LEFT +RIGHT ^GUESSNOUNROOT
! Tags for derivation +adda +ahtti +alla +asti +aš +d +eaddji +eamoš +eapmi +g +geahtes +h +heapmi +hudda +huhtti +huvva +j +l +laš +las +meahttun +muš +n +š +st +stuvva +upmi +us +vuohta +goahti +lágan +Dimin
section.p: The reason why there is a Multichar_Symbols section is that without it, lexc (the morphological program) would have treated them as separate letters (+Pron as +, P, r, o and n) instead of as tags. Since all tags are marked with an initial "+", all grammatical tags are found in the list. Note that in order to disambiguate text (with the program vislcg), we strip the pluses and instead represent the words as "<biilla> N Sg Acc" instead.

Note that the derivational tags "represent themselves", i.e., words derived with the suffix "-laš" will get the tag +laš, etc. Another possibility šould have been to declare a tag "+Der/laš". This has been done for Lule Sámi.
These are the main parts of speech (POS) for Northern Sámi:
Nouns, adjectives, verbs, pronouns, adverbs, particles, subjunctions, conjunctions, adpositions, postpositions, prepositions and interjections.

section.title: The nouns
section.p: The string is "+N+Number+Case+Possessivesuffix+Clitic". The word form "biilasgo" is thus analysed as "biila+N+Sg+Gen+PxSg3+Clt".
Here is a list of the nominal tags, given in the same order as for the analysis. Note that the grammatical categories in parentheses can be omitted.

section.title: The adjectives
section.p: Used non-attributively the adjective resembles the noun:
Used attributively the adjective has a quite simple tag scheme:

section.title: The verbs
section.p: Finite and infinite verb forms have quite distinct paradigms. Finite first:
Infinite verb forms:
Other derived verb forms:
Here is an example: "addit" > addit+V+N+Actor+Pl+Nom
These tags are still not documented: +Act +Neg +ImprtII

section.title: The pronouns
section.p: The personal, demonstrative and interrogative pronouns:
baseform+Pron+Pers+Number+Case
Example:

mun+Pron+Pers+Sg+Com
dat+Pron+Dem+Pl+Nom
The reflexive pronouns:
baseform+Pron+pronoun_type+Case(+possessive suffix)
Example: ies1+Pron+Refl+Loc+PxDu1

section.title: The Incdeclinable words
section.p: These have their POS tag as their only tag:
section.source: underlying form: birra+Adp surface form: birra

section.title: Grammatical function tags
section.p: In May 2005 we introduced gramamtical function tags (@SUBJ, @OBJ, etc.), based upon a compromise between the Sámi gramamtical tradition and the conventions found in the visl project .

section.title: A systematic grouping of the tags
section.p: The Sámi disambiguation file sme-dis.rle adds syntactic tags th each cohort.

section.title: The verb tags
section.p: This set seems ok: We have finite and infine main and auxiliary verbs.

section.title: The major function tags
section.p: The four main functions for subject, object and their predicatives are obvious.
The @SUBJ-QH is a tag for quantifier heads of nouns. This goes both for singular and plural quantifiers.
The @-FSUBJ is a tag for subjects of infinite verbs, like mu in Diet dáhpáhuvai mu dieđikeahttá. The tag hits rarely, e.g. not once in our corpus of bureaucratic texts.

section.title: The adverbial tags
section.p: The @ADV-A tag is for adverbs modifying adjectives, and the @ADV-ADV tag is for adverbs modifying adverbs.
The @ADVL tag is obvious.
Discussion: We should consider unifying some of the adverbial tags. Against unification speak the possibilites of using the fine-grained distinctions in the disambiguation.

section.title: The NP-internal modifiers
section.p: The @NUM-PRON tag is for numerals modifying pronouns to their left, like in Mii golmmas finaimet máná geahčen.
The @NUMBER tag is for numerals that only represent numbering, not amount.

The @MEASURE tag is for measure words standing as complements of numerals, and acting as classifiers, like "miilla" and "jagi" in Ádjá viessu lea guokte miilla bajábeal márkana. Dat dáhpáhuvai golbma jagi maŋŋil.,
The @TIME tag is for numerals denoting time, like "2004" in Dat dáhpáhuvai jagi 2004, iige odne. In this example, only "2004" gets the @TIME tag, not "odne".
There are 10 tags for constituents modifying a noun from the left, selecting, adjective, Actio, Determiner, Genitive noun or pronoun, proper noun, participle, pronoun or quantifier.
Discussion: The quantifier modifying N is for the oblique cases like Son lea viđa jági boaris.
There are 5 tags for constituents modifying from the right, quantifiers (@QN<) and pronouns (@PronN<) modifying nouns, and nouns modifying pronouns (@NPRON<) and quantifiers (@NQ<).

section.title: An alphabetic list of tags
section.p: Here is a list of tags, with a definition or description and example following each of them

dl.dd:
Finite auxiliary verb.
"<lea>" ("<Ráđđehussii lea geavatlaš politihkka deaŧalaš. >")

Finite main verb.
“<boađe>” (“<Boađe boahtte vahku.>”)

Infinite auxiliary verb.
“<sáhte>” (“<Eat mii sáhte vuolgit.>“)

Infinite main verb.
“<geargan>” (“<Ja Biret-Elle lea easka skuvllas geargan.>”)

Subject of infinite verb, e.g. of Actio Gen.
"<diet>" ("<Diet dáhpáhuvai mu dieđikeahttá.>")

Adverb modifying an adjective.
"<nu>" ("<Gulahallan Sámedikkiin dán gažaldagas šaddá nu konkrehtalažžan go vejolaš.>")

Adverb modifying an adverb.
“<man>” (“<Man dávjá mun livččen dáhtton čohkket du mánáid.>”)

Adverbial.
"<ráđđehussii>" ("<Ráđđehussii lea geavatlaš politihkka deaŧalaš. >")

Prenominal adjective modifier.
"<geavatlaš>" ("<Ráđđehussii lea geavatlaš politihkka deaŧalaš. >")
Actio Nominative. This tag is problematic! "<dahkan>" (“<Sii orro sin iežaset dahkan darfegođiid siste.>”)

Conjunction.
"<muhto>" (“Na muhto don it leat dasa nama čállán!”)

This is the syntactic parallel of the morphological Cmpnd tag, used to mark the first part of expressions like mánáid- ja nuoraidprykiatriija.
"<oahppo->" ("<Oahppo- ja dutkanministtar dat lea ráhkadan dieđáhusa alit sámi oahpu ja dutkama birra.>")

Subjunction.
"<go>" (“<Leago guhkes áigi dassá go Máreha oidnet?”>)

Prenominal determiner, modifier.
"<dáid>" ("<Politihkalaččat lea govdes ovttamielatvuohta dáid váldolinjáid hárrái Stuorradikkis.>")

Preadijectival genitive modifier. It is mapped after the
            @GN> tag and thus not in conflict with it. 
“<girjji>”
            (“<Duon guovtti girjji buoret dat gal lea.>”)

Prenominal genitive modifier.
“<iežat >” (“<Diet lea du iežat ášši.>”)

Genitive complement of postposition.
"<oahpu>", "<dutkama>" ("<Oahppo- ja dutkanministtar dat lea ráhkadan dieđáhusa alit sámi oahpu ja dutkama birra.>")

Genitive complement of preposition.
“<oasálaččaid>” (“<Finnmárkkus ii goassige leat leamaš ságastallan gaskal muhtun muddui seammadássásaš oasálaččaid.>”)
Genitive complement of quantifier.

Stray noun in sentence fragments.
“<boddu>” (“<Vuosttaš boddu.>”)

Interjection.
“<maid>” (“<Maid, iigo leat boahtán?>”)
Complement of numerals. Consider using @NQ<. “<mehtera>” (“<Min viessu lea vihtta mehtara alu.>”)

Noun modifying pronouns to the left.
“<ipmašiid>” (“<Maid ipmašiid doppe dagat?>”)

Noun modifying quantifier noun to the left.
“<oahppi>” (“<Joavkkus leat vihtta oahppi Kárášjogas.>”)

e.
“<golmmas>” (“<Mii golmmas oktan du vieljain finaimet Niillas-čeazi geahčen.>”)

Isolated numeral: s. 240. Kapihttal 3 ja 4.
"<I>" ("<Dieđáhusa oasis I ovdanbuktojuvvo Ovttasbargoráđđehusa sámepolitihkalaš vuođđolávdi.>")

Direct object.
“<áiggi>” (“<Dat gáibida ollu áiggi.>“)

Object predicative.
“<oassin>” ("<Oassin globaliseremis jápmet eatnat gielat máilmmis.>")

Particle.
“<amma>” (“<Amma mii eat leat máksán?>”)

Complement of particle.
"<vejolaš>" ("<Gulahallan Sámedikkiin dán gažaldagas šaddá nu konkrehtalažžan go vejolaš.>")

Syntactic tag for proper noun attributes, of the type "Tove" in "Tove Bull".
“<Tove>" ("<Rektor Tove Bull álgaga mielde...>”)

Present participle modifying noun to the right.
“<mannan>” (“<Ii leat boahtán mannan váhkus.>”)

Pronoun modifying a noun to the right.
“<juohke>” (“<Galgá gávdnot divššohasbearráigeahčči juohke fylkkas.>”)

Pronoun modifying a noun to the left.
“<goappašat> (“<Soai leaba goappašagat nu jallat.>”)

Prenominal quantifier, modifier.
“<ovtta>” (“<Galgá čájehit vuollegašvuođa juohke ovtta divššohasa eallimii.>”)

Quantifier modifying noun to the left.
“<vihtta>” (“<Mun boađan diibmu vihtta.>”)

Subject predicative.
"<deaŧalaš>" ("<Ráđđehussii lea geavatlaš politihkka deaŧalaš. >")

Subject.
"<politihkka>" ("<Ráđđehussii lea geavatlaš politihkka deaŧalaš. >")
Subject with a quantifier head. 10 jági lea vássán. Okta dain doaimmain lea redigeret ja čorget journála. "<máŋggat>" ("<Boazodoalus leat máŋggat hástalusat ovddabealde. >")

Numeral as apposition to the noun "year".
“<1897>” (“<Sápmelaččat leat jagi 1897 lihkostuvvan cealkit riektái, ahte...>”)

Vocative.
“<hearrá>” (“<Hearrá, du ráhkis ustit lea buohcci.>”)
A dummy tag assigned when no tag assignment rule has hit. This tag is useful for finding the flaws in the tag mapping section.

section.title: The present visl tags for Finnish

tr.td: Minulla on auto. Paketti painaa kilon. meidän kannattaa mennä kotiin. Kankaasta tuli takki. Hän itki viikon.

section.p: Last modified: $Date$, by $Author$
